bestBHT.bht: Take encouragement from the parable of the unjust judge, the judge of injustice. The Lord, with His authoritative style, interprets the parable to emphasize the need for persistent prayer. Just as the unjust judge responded to the importunate requests, how much more will God regard the fervent pleas and arise to save. So be frequent and importunate in prayer with God, for even impudence against Him is profitable.

Henry Alford: 6. the unjust judge] literally (see above) the judge of injustice—i. e. who was of, belonged to, the unrighteousness which is in the world.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: expressive of the authoritative style in which He interprets
Albert Barnes: Hear ... - Give attention to this, and derive from it practical instruction.
Marvin Vincent: The unjust judge. Lit., the judge of injustice. See on ch. Luke 16:8.
Philip Schaff: Luke 18:6. The unjust judge, lit, ‘the judge of unrighteousness.’ This is emphatic to lead to the conclusion in Luke 18:7.
Archibald T. Robertson: The unrighteous judge (ο κριτης της αδικιας). The judge of unrighteousness (marked by unrighteousness), as in Luke 16:8 we have "the steward of unrighteousness," the same idiom.
John Gill: Take encouragement from hence to be frequent and importunate in prayer with God.
How much more will not God... regard their importunate requests, and arise, and save them...
Impudence (i.e. importunity) even against God is profitable.

bhtAttempts.bht: Take encouragement and derive practical instruction from the parable of the unjust judge who belonged to the unrighteousness of the world. The Lord, expressing His authoritative style, uses this parable to emphasize the need for persistent and frequent prayer. Just as the unjust judge responded to the importunate requests of the widow, how much more will God, who is just and righteous, regard the fervent pleas of His people and arise to save them. So be persistent and bold in your prayers, for even impudence, or importunity, against God can be profitable.

Take encouragement and practical instruction from the parable of the unjust judge who belonged to the unrighteousness of the world. The Lord, expressing His authoritative style, emphasizes the need for persistent and frequent prayer. Just as the judge responded to the importunate requests of the widow, how much more will God, who is just and righteous, regard the fervent pleas of His people and arise to save them. So be persistent and bold in your prayers, for even importunity against God can be profitable.

Take encouragement from the parable of the unjust judge, who was of the unrighteousness in the world. The Lord uses this parable to express His authority and to teach the importance of persistent and frequent prayer. Just as the judge responded to the importunate requests of the widow, how much more will God hear and answer the fervent pleas of His people. Be bold and persistent in your prayers, for even impudence against God can be profitable.

Take encouragement from the parable of the unjust judge, belonging to the world's unrighteousness. The Lord, with His authoritative style, emphasizes the need for persistent prayer. Just as the unjust judge responded to the importunate requests of the widow, God will surely hear and save those who fervently plead. Be persistent and bold in prayer, for even impudence against God can be profitable.

Take encouragement from the parable of the unjust judge, the judge of injustice. The Lord, with His authoritative style, interprets the parable to emphasize the need for persistent prayer. Just as the unjust judge responded to the importunate requests, how much more will God regard the fervent pleas and arise to save. So be frequent and importunate in prayer with God, for even impudence against Him is profitable.
